content: That is a comcast email server issue to resolve. Thunderbird is a email retriever and send through comcast by itself it does nothing with a email server to connect to. Also this is Browser help forum there is a Thunderbird forum that you should post Thunderbird issue to as well.
creator: markwarner22

content: This post appears to be in the Help/Support Forums/Thunderbird/. Is there another place I should be asking this question? I don't understand markwarner22's reply. My problem is: 100s of spam emails come into my thunderbird account from my Comcast.net email address that never appear in the Xfinity webmail page. When I go to Xfinity's webmail webpage, none of these spam emails appear anywhere. Neither in its Inbox or Spam folder. They're just not there. But somehow, when Thunderbird "retrieves" email from that account, it "retrieves" all these invisible spam emails from somewhere. It appears Thunderbird gets them before Xfinity (Comcast) filters them out. BTW, I have no filters set up on the Xfinity webpage. So however Xfinity gets rid of the spam, it does it on its own.
creator: ralphco

content:
Hi Ralphco,

Layman's guess: Comcast is adding headers to identify those messages as junk, but Thunderbird ignores those headers unless you tell it what to do.

In account settings - junk settings, is "Trust junk mail headers set by:" selected? If so, which filter is selected in the drop-down list?

You may have to contact Comcast to learn which spam filter they use, and hope that it is in the drop-down list.

Rick
creator: mozilla664

content:
Qualsiasi allegato? Di qualsiasi formato?

Inoltre, Informazioni utili da fornire nelle richieste al forum:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird
  7. Software di sicurezza eventualmente presenti (Antivirus e simili)

content: This appears to be a file problem. When thunderbird closes, it updates the prefs.js file with that information. If the file is read-only or otherwise unavailable, the result is as you describe. this may be an antivirus or VPN or firewall interferring. You may also see multiple prefs files, such as prefs-1.js, etc. If unfamiliar with accessing profile, you can do this: - click help>troubleshootinginformation - scroll down to 'profile folder' on left side and click 'open folder' - you are now in profile. exit thunderbird - if there are multiple entries for prefs.js, rename the one with highest number to prefs.js after deleting the original. That may work.
creator: davidsk

content: Dipende da come sono andate perse. In generale ci vuole un backup. Poi a seconda dei casi possono esserci altre strade.
creator: @next

content:
Kunt u een voorbeeld delen (waar de privacygevoelige gegevens uit zijn verwijderd)?

U zou de volgende zaken eens kunnen proberen:

  • De map waarin de berichten staan repareren: klik met uw rechtermuisknop op de map, selecteer Eigenschappen en vervolgens Map repareren.
  • Een nieuw profiel aanmaken: probeer of u in een ‘vers’ profiel hetzelfde probleem ervaart.
  • Als u opnieuw installeren geen bezwaar zou vinden, verwijder dan Thunderbird en verwijder ook uw profielmappen. Bij een herinstallatie zonder verwijdering ‘ziet’ het programma namelijk het oude profiel en gebruikt het dat om de instellingen e.d. te herstellen, en als daar de fout in zit, dan krijgt u die weer terug.

De twee laatste bovenstaande punten werken prima als u IMAP gebruikt; bij POP ziet u uw eerder opgehaalde berichten niet meer terug.
creator: markh2

content: If you have created the account, you can go to settings>privacy&security, click savedpasswords and then showpasswords. That does NOT work, however, if the account uses an 'app' password (such as Gmail). Otherwise, you need to retrieve email password from email provider.
